comment.author: 17264356@N00
comment._content: "Nan is already a spoiled child" wonder what that meant to the source of the line?

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: More about "spoiled" Anna J. Gallant (1902-1936): sevensteeples.com/gallant1.html She was mother to Maurice Roy Sears (1920- 1985), and wife to Carroll Ernest Sears (married 1922). She only lived to age 34, but there are photos of her as an adult, on the fourth page of the same website: sevensteeples.com/gallant4.html

comment.author: 17264356@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02] That's a great story, thanks for finding it.

After seeing this poster from Hines:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/7985821192/]

I'm thinking that perhaps the "spoiled" description is not the modern definition of spoiled by pampering, but a more general sense of decayed, or marred, induced by the soul-deadening work.
